awd_titl_txt: Polar Peoples:   Past, Present, and Future
awd_abstract_narration:
This award will support a project to examine population trends across the Arctic in the past, the present, and into the future, using tools of demographic and geographic analysis. The project will describe temporal and spatial trends in the size and composition of the Arctic populations, examine the causes of these changes, and the implications of these trends for the economies and societies of the Arctic regions and countries. Three different time periods will be examined, each using different data and methods and exploring different question. The three time periods are: The Past, which examines the period from the first International Polar Year (IPY) in 1882-1883, the time of increased exploration of the Polar regions and start of intense interaction between the indigenous peoples of the Arctic and outsiders, to the most recent IPY of 2007-2008; The Present, which is an analysis of current population trends in the Arctic is based on data from 2010 round of population censuses and other current demographic statistics; and The Future, which is an examination of future population trends in the Arctic that projects out one generation to 2050. 

With globalization, climate change, technological advances, as well as drivers of demographic change, which are occurring elsewhere in the world, the populations of the Arctic regions are poised to undergo considerable transformation over the next generation. The project will result in articles in academic journals, a book, policy briefs and a conference which brings together researchers, government demographers, and policy makers from across the Arctic. This project will make these important analyses and data easily accessible to researchers, community members, and policy makers. By making these data and analyses easily accessible by these diverse Arctic stakeholders, the project ensures that future decision making can be based on actual data and analysis not just perceived trends.

por.por_cntn:
Project Outcomes - Polar Peoples: Past, Present, and Future

 Polar Peoples examined population trends across the Arctic over the past, the present, and into the future, using tools of demographic and geographic analysis to describe temporal and spatial trends in the size and composition of the Arctic populations, examine the causes of these changes, and the implications of these trends for the economies and societies of the Arctic regions and countries. Three different time periods were examined in Polar Peoples, each using different data and methods and different hypotheses.

Polar Peoples: Past, Present, and Future is a story about the people who have lived the cold, distant regions collectively known as the Artic. It is about the people who were born, lived in, and died in the region and about those who chose to migration to or away from the region or from place to place within the Arctic. It tells how people in the Arctic have been impacted by global political, technological, and economic events and trends, including climate change. The size and composition of the population of any region is made of many individuals. These individuals differ by age, sex, ethnicity, marital status, occupation, and other characteristics. Population change is collectively the result of decisions people make about whether and how many children to have, health and well-being decisions which impact their mortality, and choices about whether to migrate to another place or not. While the population of the Arctic constitutes only a small portion of the world?s population, it is spread out over a vast area. Thus, one defining characteristic of the Arctic is that it is quite sparsely populated compared to other parts of the world. Much of the Arctic?s population is clustered into small or medium size settlements with vast uninhabited areas between them. There are few very large cities in the Arctic. The Arctic regions share being located at high latitudes and having very cold climates. The populations of the Arctic must confront these unique challenges posed by the region?s physical characteristics. The Arctic indigenous populations had their own demographic challenges when outsiders first moved into their regions. While many of the factors influencing the size and structure of the Arctic population are like those found elsewhere, the are many unique characteristics and dynamics as this project examined.

Intellectual merit: Polar Peoples produced articles in academic journals, book chapters, presentations, and policy briefs. A book manuscript with the title of project has been drafted. Among the topics covered were projections of the Arctic populations, how governments classify Arctic populations, population change in Arctic regions, reasons for changing gender composition among Arctic populations, population living on permafrost in the Arctic, the population history of Alaska Natives, the demographic transition of Arctic populations, and migration in the Arctic.

 Broader impacts: Analysis of the future was a combination of demographic projections, modeling, and fieldwork in the region to determine the size, composition, and distribution of Arctic population as well factors driving these trends and their implications. Analysis of past and present drivers and impacts of population change across the Arctic will allow for better planning of the future. Population projections of the Arctic countries and regions were analyzed as a tool for policy makers and others to understand the likely future size and composition of their populations. Analysis of the population living on permafrost in the Arctic was combined with projections of future permafrost extent to determine the impact of permafrost thaw. The project also provided experience and training to two young scholars who received MAs in Geography to assist with the development of the next generation of Arctic social scientists. One of whom now works in the Office of the Geographer at the U.S. Department of State.
